claim: The trails left in the sky by aircraft are water-based.

supporting.text: Aircraft engine exhaust contains water vapor as a byproduct of fuel combustion, which can condense into visible trails under certain atmospheric conditions.

attacks.text: Aircraft engine exhaust contains water vapor as a byproduct of fuel combustion, which can condense into visible trails under certain atmospheric conditions.
Some aircraft trails contain persistent chemical compounds, not just water vapor, as evidenced by atmospheric sampling studies.
The persistence and spread of certain trails contradict pure water condensation behavior, suggesting additional particulate matter.
Military aircraft have been documented releasing non-water-based materials for operational purposes, unrelated to combustion byproducts.
Standard commercial aviation fuel combustion does not produce the chemical signatures found in some anomalous trail samples.

supporting.text: The trails formed behind aircraft are primarily composed of ice crystals formed from the freezing of water vapor in the exhaust at high altitudes.

attacks.text: The trails formed behind aircraft are primarily composed of ice crystals formed from the freezing of water vapor in the exhaust at high altitudes.
Some aircraft trails contain persistent chemical compounds, suggesting they are not purely water-based.
The presence of chemical compounds in aircraft trails is negligible compared to the overwhelming majority of water vapor and ice crystals.
In rare cases, aircraft trails can contain pollutants or byproducts from incomplete fuel combustion.
Modern aircraft engines are highly efficient and minimize incomplete combustion, making such pollutants extremely rare.

supporting.text: Scientific studies confirm that contrails (condensation trails) are formed when hot, humid exhaust from aircraft engines mixes with cold, low-pressure air in the upper atmosphere.

attacks.text: Scientific studies confirm that contrails (condensation trails) are formed when hot, humid exhaust from aircraft engines mixes with cold, low-pressure air in the upper atmosphere.
Some contrails persist and spread, forming cirrus-like clouds, which suggests they contain more than just water vapor.
Persistent contrails are still primarily composed of ice crystals formed from water vapor, and their spread is due to atmospheric conditions, not additional substances.
Certain conspiracy theories claim contrails contain chemicals for geoengineering, contradicting the water-based explanation.
There is no credible scientific evidence supporting the claim that contrails contain chemicals for geoengineering.

supporting.text: Meteorological data and atmospheric physics support that the trails are water-based, as they dissipate or persist based on humidity and temperature conditions aloft.

attacks.text: Meteorological data and atmospheric physics support that the trails are water-based, as they dissipate or persist based on humidity and temperature conditions aloft.
Some trails contain chemical compounds not typically found in water vapor, such as barium or aluminum, which suggests they are not purely water-based.
The presence of trace chemicals can be attributed to normal engine emissions or atmospheric contaminants, not deliberate spraying.
Persistent trails sometimes spread into artificial-looking cloud formations, which is inconsistent with natural water vapor behavior.
Atmospheric conditions like supersaturation can cause water vapor trails to spread unusually, mimicking artificial patterns.
